Topic.Title: Will Obamacare Improve the Medical Care at Hospitals in Las Vegas Nevada????

Message.Msg: "Health Plan of Nevada must pay $500 million in punitive damages for its role in the 2008 hepatitis C outbreak, a jury decided Tuesday. The same eight-member jury last week awarded $24 million in compensatory damages to three people, two of whom contracted hepatitis C at a facility operated by Dr. Dipak Desai, the central figure in the outbreak. The $524 million total award is believed to be the largest in Nevada’s history for a single case." Source: Las Vegas Review Journal, April 9 and 10, 2013.

Message.Title: Las Vegas, Nevada, could Run out of Water by 2015
Message.Msg: Lake Mead provides 90 percent of the water to Las Vegas. Demand for water from Lake Mead exceeds supply. The bathtub ring just becomes larger at Lake Mead. IMO: Las Vegas would run out of water sooner if were not for Mexico allowing 1.5 million acre feet of water to be stored in Lake Mead while the country makes repairs from an earthquake. Before Las Vegas runs out of water, Hoover Dam will cease to generate electricity. It will cause a dimming effect on Los Angeles.

Topic.Title: Las Vegas, Nevada, could Run out of Water by 2015

Message.Msg: "Winter water yield falls short Lake Mead could sink to 1,084 feet by next fall, its lowest level since 2010. Lake Mead could drop another 30 feet by 2015, dangerously close to shortage levels, according to new projections by the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation (BOR). The BOR projects Lake Mead could sink to 1,084 feet by next fall—its lowest level since 2010 and just 9 feet from triggering a federal shortage declaration, reducing Nevada and Arizona's available Colorado River water. The projections follow a mild winter and an unseasonably warm spring, drying up any hope of increased run-off. The Colorado River system depends on snowmelt from the Rockies to feed tributaries that flow into the river and subsequently lakes Powell and Mead. Lake Mead has dropped more than 90 feet since the drought began over a decade ago, and another BOR study predicts those challenging conditions will persist. The study—funded by the SNWA, other agencies representing the Colorado River Basin States and the BOR—offers recommendations to supplement existing supplies including increased water conservation and reuse, desalination and other augmentation projects. The U.S. and Mexico recently entered an innovative agreement to temporarily shore up Lake Mead levels. Minute No. 319 allows Mexico to store as much as 1.5 million acre-feet of water in Lake Mead while repairs are being made to that country’s water infrastructure, which was damaged in a 2010 earthquake. Nevada receives approximately 300,000 acre-feet of Colorado River water annually. One acre-foot of water is enough to supply two average homes for one year." Source: Southern Nevada Water Authority.

Message.Title: Truth about the IRS "scandal"
Message.Msg: NYT "While there are still many gaps in the story of how the I.R.S. scandal happened, interviews with current and former employees and with lawyers who dealt with them, along with a review of I.R.S. documents, paint a more muddled picture of an understaffed Cincinnati outpost that was alienated from the broader I.R.S. culture and given little direction. Overseen by a revolving cast of midlevel managers, stalled by miscommunication with I.R.S. lawyers and executives in Washington and confused about the rules they were enforcing, the Cincinnati specialists flagged virtually every application with Tea Party in its name. But their review went beyond conservative groups: more than 400 organizations came under scrutiny, including at least two dozen liberal-leaning ones and some that were seemingly apolitical."

Treasury Department officials were told about the investigation into the treatment of tea party groups in June 2012 - months before last year's the Presidential election. Republicans who requested the investigation were also told about it at approximately the same time. In a letter dated July 11, 2012, the man who conducted the investigation - IRS inspector general J. Russell George - wrote to Rep. Darrell Issa, the chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, telling him that he was investigating the issue and offering to keep him updated as the investigation progressed. "The Oversight Committee knew about the audit because it requested it," an Issa aide told ABC News. Issa released the letter, along with his own letter dated June 28, 2012 requesting the investigation, last week.

Topic.Title: Will Stem Cell Therapy Eliminate Bypass Surgery in the next 5 Years?

Message.Msg: Bypass surgery for coronary artery disease. Yale University Medical Center and the University School of Medicine are working the use of stem cell therapy.

Topic.Title: Will Stem Cell Therapy Eliminate Bypass Surgery in the next 5 Years?

Message.Msg: """"Nearly a year ago, we posted about British researchers from Bristol University who are looking at stem cells to cure heart diseases. Now, a heart patient named John Christy who was suffering from severe coronary artery disease has been saved by stem cells harvested taken from his bone marrow and which were injected to his heart. According to ABC News Christy, a war veteran, is the first man in the United States to undergo the procedure. The successful treatment was conducted by Dr. Joseph Woo a cardiothoracic surgeon at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine. More from ABC News: “After five years of research in animals, he [Dr. Woo, editor] is now retrieving stem cells from Christy’s bone marrow and using them to grow blood vessels around the heart. “They form brand new micro blood vessels and deliver blood flow to the heart muscle,” said Woo. He has started the first U.S. trial where stem cells are harvested during surgery, prepped and then re-inserted back into the patient’s own heart. … Woo says any patient who is a candidate for coronary bypass surgery is a good candidate for his stem-cell transplant.”""" Source: Health Care Zone.

Topic.Title: Will Stem Cell Therapy Eliminate Bypass Surgery in the next 5 Years?

Message.Msg: sound fine. However, not everyone has healthy bone marrow. Leukemia patients for example

Topic.Title: Will Stem Cell Therapy Eliminate Bypass Surgery in the next 5 Years?

Message.Msg: An article entitled "Artery formation process discovered" in the U-T San Diego online on April 29, 2013. I do not believe their discovery involved bone the use of bone marrow. The lead researchers are Michael Simons of Yale and Christina Ruhrberg of UCL.

Message.Title: "Artery Formation Process Discovered"
Message.Msg: """"Artery formation process discovered By Bradley J. Fikes9 a.m.April 29, 2013 A molecular mechanism prompting growth of new arteries has been discovered by a team led by scientists from Yale University and University College London. The newly discovered pathway may lead to developing drugs to encourage arteriogenesis after heart attacks and strokes. A paper describing the findings was published online Monday in the journal Developmental Cell. It is one of three papers relating to blood vessel growth published in the journal Monday. The process of angiogenesis, the growth of capillaries, has been explored for decades by scientists, most notably the late Judah Folkman, who investigated how to stop the process in cancer. On the flip side, encouraging this growth is being investigated to help repair damage caused by heart attacks. However, capillaries aren't enough. Promoting the growth of new arteries, or arteriogenesis is essential to bring in enough blood supply to regrow dead heart muscle. While arteriogenesis and angiogenesis are related, they are not the same."""

"""The process of arteriogenesis is complicated, relying on a molecular trio working in harmony. These include two growth factors, VEGF-1 and VEGF-2. A third molecule, NRP1, transports these molecules to the proper place in blood vessel walls to start regrowth. The Yale-UCL study found that a certain part of NRP1 called the cytoplasmic tail is necessary is necessary for arteriogenesis, although angiogenesis is unaffected. The lead researchers are Michael Simons of Yale and Christiana Ruhrberg of UCL. "We show that mice with a knockin mutation that ablates the NRP1 cytoplasmic tail (Nrp1cyto) have normal angiogenesis but impaired developmental and adult arteriogenesis," the study stated. The malformed NRP1 fail to activate a pathway involving ERK, or extracellular-signal-regulated kinases, enzymes involved in arteriogenesis. The paper is titled, "The Neuropilin-1 cytoplasmic domain is required for VEGF-A-dependent arteriogenesis". The other papers are: "Arterial And Venous Progenitors Of The Major Axial Vessels Originate At Distinct Locations" and: "CASZ1 Promotes Vascular Assembly and Morphogenesis Through the Direct Regulation of an EGFL7/RhoA-mediated pathway". (Clicking on the above links will take you to the complete papers, once the links are live.) © Copyright 2013 The San Diego Union-Tribune, LLC. An MLIM LLC Company. All rights reserved.""" No copyright infringement intended. Fair Use.

Topic.Title: Will Stem Cell Therapy Eliminate Bypass Surgery in the next 5 Years?

Message.Msg: it is amazing at all the advances in medicine. They often use the poor to research these experiments on, so that when they have all the errors out of the system, they can use it on the well to do and expect excellent results. Much cancer research used the poor or those without adequate health insurance as guinea pigs, when the patient died or was to live a crippled up life, they didn't care.

Topic.Title: Will Stem Cell Therapy Eliminate Bypass Surgery in the next 5 Years?

Message.Msg: I personally suffer from coronary artery disease. Currently, I have 8 drug eluting stents. Also, I have had bypass surgery with two bypass grafts for the LAD (left descending artery). At one time I used to wear a nitroglycerin patch 12 hours per day to eliminate left shoulder and arm pain. The nitroglycerin caused me to have ulcerative colitis. My very smart primary care physician, at the time, decided to use Percocet for pain from colitis but for off label to relax my arteries and relief the left shoulder and arm pain. It worked and continues to work. Also, I have been at Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla. I cannot stress how great the treatment was there.
